During the SolarWinds Compromise, APT29 granted company administrator privileges to a newly created service principle.[24]

APT29 has enrolled their own devices into compromised cloud tenants, including enrolling a device in MFA to an Azure AD environment following a successful password guessing attack against a dormant account.[33][34]During the SolarWinds Compromise, APT29 registered devices in order to enable mailbox syncing via the Set-CASMailbox command.[12]

For the SolarWinds Compromise, APT29 acquired C2 domains, sometimes through resellers.[10][35]For Operation Ghost, APT29 registered domains for use in C2 including some crafted to appear as existing legitimate domains.[22]

APT29 has registered algorithmically generated Twitter handles that are used for C2 by malware, such as HAMMERTOSS. APT29 has also used legitimate web services such as Dropbox and Constant Contact in their operations.[36][18]
APT29 has conducted widespread scanning of target environments to identify vulnerabilities for exploit.[13]
During the SolarWinds Compromise, APT29 used HTTP for C2 and data exfiltration.[12]

Full_Technique_Name: Archive Collected Data: Archive via Utility
Use: During the SolarWinds Compromise, APT29 used 7-Zip to compress stolen emails into password-protected archives prior to exfltration; APT29 also compressed text files into zipped archives.[12][37][24]

Full_Technique_Name: Boot or Logon Autostart Execution: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
Use: APT29 added Registry Run keys to establish persistence.[30]
APT29 has hijacked legitimate application-specific startup scripts to enable malware to execute on system startup.[27]
APT29 has installed a run command on a compromised system to enable malware execution on system startup.[27]
APT29 has successfully conducted password guessing attacks against a list of mailboxes.[33]
APT29 has conducted brute force password spray attacks.[20][31][34]
APT29 has used Azure Run Command and Azure Admin-on-Behalf-of (AOBO) to execute code on virtual machines.[31]

APT29 has used encoded PowerShell scripts uploaded to CozyCar installations to download and install SeaDuke.[38][30][39][16]During the SolarWinds Compromise, APT29 used PowerShell to create new tasks on remote machines, identify configuration settings, exfiltrate data, and execute other commands.[12][40][24]

Full_Technique_Name: Command and Scripting Interpreter: Windows Command Shell
Use: During the SolarWinds Compromise, APT29 used cmd.exe to execute commands on remote machines.[12][40]

Full_Technique_Name: Command and Scripting Interpreter: Visual Basic
Use: For the SolarWinds Compromise, APT29 wrote malware such as Sibot in Visual Basic.[13]
APT29 has developed malware variants written in Python.[38]

Full_Technique_Name: Command and Scripting Interpreter: Cloud API
Use: APT29 has leveraged the Microsoft Graph API to perform various actions across Azure and M365 environments. They have also utilized AADInternals PowerShell Modules to access the API [19]
APT29 has compromised email accounts to further enable phishing campaigns and taken control of dormant accounts.[41][33]
APT29 has used residential proxies, including Azure Virtual Machines, to obfuscate their access to victim environments.[33]
For the SolarWinds Compromise, APT29 compromised domains to use for C2.[10]
APT29 can create new users through Azure AD.[31]

Full_Technique_Name: Credentials from Password Stores: Credentials from Web Browsers
Use: During the SolarWinds Compromise, APT29 stole users' saved passwords from Chrome.[24]
During the SolarWinds Compromise, APT29 accessed victims' internal knowledge repositories (wikis) to view sensitive corporate information on products, services, and internal business operations.[24]
During the SolarWinds Compromise, APT29 downloaded source code from code repositories.[42]
APT29 has stolen data from compromised hosts.[27]During the SolarWinds Compromise, APT29 extracted files from compromised networks.[12]
During Operation Ghost, APT29 used steganography to hide the communications between the implants and their C&C servers.[22]
During the SolarWinds Compromise, APT29 staged data and files in password-protected archives on a victim's OWA server.[12]
During the SolarWinds Compromise, APT29 used 7-Zip to decode their Raindrop malware.[43]

APT29 has used unique malware in many of their operations.[3][30][19][27]For the SolarWinds Compromise, APT29 used numerous pieces of malware that were likely developed for or by the group, including SUNBURST, SUNSPOT, Raindrop, and TEARDROP.[9][11][37] For Operation Ghost, APT29 used new strains of malware including FatDuke, MiniDuke, RegDuke, and PolyglotDuke.[22]
APT29 has created self-signed digital certificates to enable mutual TLS authentication for malware.[25][26]

Full_Technique_Name: Domain or Tenant Policy Modification: Trust Modification
Use: During the SolarWinds Compromise, APT29 changed domain federation trust settings using Azure AD administrative permissions to configure the domain to accept authorization tokens signed by their own SAML signing certificate.[15][44]

During the SolarWinds Compromise, APT29 used the Get-AcceptedDomain PowerShell cmdlet to enumerate accepted domains through an Exchange Management Shell.[12] They also used AdFind to enumerate domains and to discover trust between federated domains.[24][37]

APT29 has used Dynamic DNS providers for their malware C2 infrastructure.[27]During the SolarWinds Compromise, APT29 used dynamic DNS resolution to construct and resolve to randomly-generated subdomains for C2.[12]

APT29 has collected emails from targeted mailboxes within a compromised Azure AD tenant and compromised Exchange servers, including via Exchange Web Services (EWS) API requests.[33][27]During the SolarWinds Compromise, APT29 collected emails from specific individuals, such as executives and IT staff, using New-MailboxExportRequest followed by Get-MailboxExportRequest.[12][13]
APT29 has used multiple layers of encryption within malware to protect C2 communication.[16]
For Operation Ghost, APT29 registered Twitter accounts to host C2 nodes.[22]

Full_Technique_Name: Event Triggered Execution: Windows Management Instrumentation Event Subscription
Use: APT29 has used WMI event subscriptions for persistence.[30]During the SolarWinds Compromise, APT29 used a WMI event filter to invoke a command-line event consumer at system boot time to launch a backdoor with rundll32.exe.[37][44]During Operation Ghost, APT29 used WMI event subscriptions to establish persistence for malware.[22]
APT29 used sticky-keys to obtain unauthenticated, privileged console access.[30][45]

Sub_Technique_Name: Exfiltration Over Asymmetric Encrypted Non-C2 Protocol
Full_Technique_Name: Exfiltration Over Alternative Protocol: Exfiltration Over Asymmetric Encrypted Non-C2 Protocol
Use: During the SolarWinds Compromise, APT29 exfiltrated collected data over a simple HTTPS request to a password-protected archive staged on a victim's OWA servers.[12]

APT29 has exploited CVE-2019-19781 for Citrix, CVE-2019-11510 for Pulse Secure VPNs, CVE-2018-13379 for FortiGate VPNs, and CVE-2019-9670 in Zimbra software to gain access.[13][23]During the SolarWinds Compromise, APT29 exploited CVE-2020-0688 against the Microsoft Exchange Control Panel to regain access to a network.[12][13]
APT29 has used multiple software exploits for common client software, like Microsoft Word, Exchange, and Adobe Reader, to gain code execution.[3][13][18]
APT29 has exploited CVE-2021-36934 to escalate privileges on a compromised host.[39]

APT29 has used compromised identities to access networks via VPNs and Citrix.[23][33]For the SolarWinds Compromise, APT29 used compromised identities to access networks via SSH, VPNs, and other remote access tools.[10][24]
During the SolarWinds Compromise, APT29 obtained information about the configured Exchange virtual directory using Get-WebServicesVirtualDirectory.[12]
During the SolarWinds Compromise, APT29 bypassed MFA set on OWA accounts by generating a cookie value from a previously stolen secret key.[12]
During the SolarWinds Compromise, APT29 created tokens using compromised SAML signing certificates.[32][15]
For the SolarWinds Compromise, APT29 conducted credential theft operations to obtain credentials to be used for access to victim environments.[24]

APT29 uses compromised residential endpoints, typically within the same ISP IP address range, as proxies to hide the true source of C2 traffic.[34]During the SolarWinds Compromise, APT29 set the hostnames of their C2 infrastructure to match legitimate hostnames in the victim environment. They also used IP addresses originating from the same country as the victim for their VPN infrastructure.[9]

Full_Technique_Name: Impair Defenses: Disable or Modify Tools
Use: During the SolarWinds Compromise, APT29 used the service control manager on a remote system to disable services associated with security monitoring products.[37]

Full_Technique_Name: Impair Defenses: Disable Windows Event Logging
Use: During the SolarWinds Compromise, APT29, used AUDITPOL to prevent the collection of audit logs.[37]

Full_Technique_Name: Impair Defenses: Disable or Modify System Firewall
Use: During the SolarWinds Compromise, APT29 used netsh to configure firewall rules that limited certain UDP outbound packets.[37]

Full_Technique_Name: Impair Defenses: Disable or Modify Cloud Logs
Use: APT29 has disabled Purview Audit on targeted accounts prior to stealing emails from  Microsoft 365 tenants.[33]

APT29 has used SDelete to remove artifacts from victim networks.[30]During the SolarWinds Compromise, APT29 routinely removed their tools, including custom backdoors, once remote access was achieved.[9]

APT29 has used timestomping to alter the Standard Information timestamps on their web shells to match other files in the same directory.[27]During the SolarWinds Compromise, APT29 modified timestamps of backdoors to match legitimate Windows files.[37]
During the SolarWinds Compromise, APT29 removed evidence of email export requests using Remove-MailboxExportRequest.[12]

APT29 has downloaded additional tools and malware onto compromised networks.[30][25][3][27]During the SolarWinds Compromise, APT29 downloaded additional malware, such as TEARDROP and Cobalt Strike, onto a compromised host following initial access.[9]
During the SolarWinds Compromise, APT29 named tasks \Microsoft\Windows\SoftwareProtectionPlatform\EventCacheManager in order to appear legitimate.[12]

Full_Technique_Name: Masquerading: Match Legitimate Name or Location
Use: APT29 has renamed malicious DLLs with legitimate names to appear benign; they have also created an Azure AD certificate with a Common Name that matched the display name of the compromised service principal.[17][33]During the SolarWinds Compromise, APT29 renamed software and DLLs with legitimate names to appear benign.[12][40]

APT29 has edited the Microsoft.IdentityServer.Servicehost.exe.config file to load a malicious DLL into the AD FS process, thereby enabling persistent access to any service federated with AD FS for a user with a specified User Principal Name.[46]
APT29 has used repeated MFA requests to gain access to victim accounts.[47][34]

Full_Technique_Name: Obfuscated Files or Information: Binary Padding
Use: APT29 used large size files to avoid detection by security solutions with hardcoded size limits.[17]

Full_Technique_Name: Obfuscated Files or Information: Software Packing
Use: APT29 used UPX to pack files.[30]
During Operation Ghost, APT29 used steganography to hide payloads inside valid images.[22]

Full_Technique_Name: Obfuscated Files or Information: HTML Smuggling
Use: APT29 has embedded an ISO file within an HTML attachment that contained JavaScript code to initiate malware execution.[39]
APT29 has obtained and used a variety of tools including Mimikatz, SDelete, Tor, meek, and Cobalt Strike.[30][3][27]

Full_Technique_Name: OS Credential Dumping: Security Account Manager
Use: APT29 has used the reg save command to save registry hives.[27]
APT29 has used the reg save command to extract LSA secrets offline.[27]
During the SolarWinds Compromise, APT29 used privileged accounts to replicate directory service data with domain controllers.[44][37][24]
During the SolarWinds Compromise, APT29 used AdFind to enumerate domain groups.[24]
APT29 has used spearphishing emails with an attachment to deliver files with exploits to initial victims.[3][18][39][16]
APT29 has used spearphishing with a link to trick victims into clicking on a link to a zip file containing malicious files.[30][18][48]
APT29 has used the legitimate mailing service Constant Contact to send phishing e-mails.[18]
During the SolarWinds Compromise, APT29 used multiple command-line utilities to enumerate running processes.[12][37][24]
During the SolarWinds Compromise, APT29 used SSH port forwarding capabilities on public-facing systems, and configured at least one instance of Cobalt Strike to use a network pipe over SMB.[24][43]
APT29 uses compromised residential endpoints as proxies for defense evasion and network access.[34]

A backdoor used by APT29 created a Tor hidden service to forward traffic from the Tor client to local ports 3389 (RDP), 139 (Netbios), and 445 (SMB) enabling full remote access from outside the network and has also used TOR.[30][31]
APT29 has used the meek domain fronting plugin for Tor to hide the destination of C2 traffic.[30]
During the SolarWinds Compromise, APT29 used RDP sessions from public-facing systems to internal servers.[24]
During the SolarWinds Compromise, APT29 used administrative accounts to connect over SMB to targeted users.[24]
During the SolarWinds Compromise, APT29 used WinRM via PowerShell to execute commands and payloads on remote hosts.[43]
APT29 has leveraged compromised high-privileged on-premises accounts synced to Office 365 to move laterally into a cloud environment, including through the use of Azure AD PowerShell.[49]
During the SolarWinds Compromise, APT29 used AdFind to enumerate remote systems.[37]

APT29 has used named and hijacked scheduled tasks to establish persistence.[30]During the SolarWinds Compromise, APT29 used scheduler and schtasks to create new tasks on remote host as part of their lateral movement. They manipulated scheduled tasks by updating an existing legitimate task to execute their tools and then returned the scheduled task to its original configuration. APT29 also created a scheduled task to maintain SUNSPOT persistence when the host booted.[12][9][11]
APT29 has installed web shells on exploited Microsoft Exchange servers.[13][27]
APT29 uses stolen tokens to access victim accounts, without needing a password.[34]
APT29 has abused misconfigured AD CS certificate templates to impersonate admin users and create additional authentication certificates.[50]

Full_Technique_Name: Steal or Forge Kerberos Tickets: Kerberoasting
Use: During the SolarWinds Compromise, APT29 obtained Ticket Granting Service (TGS) tickets for Active Directory Service Principle Names to crack offline.[37]
During the SolarWinds Compromise, APT29 stole Chrome browser cookies by copying the Chrome profile directories of targeted users.[24]
During the SolarWinds Compromise, APT29 was able to get SUNBURST signed by SolarWinds code signing certificates by injecting the malware into the SolarWinds Orion software lifecycle.[9]
APT29 has embedded ISO images and VHDX files in HTML to evade Mark-of-the-Web.[39]

Full_Technique_Name: Supply Chain Compromise: Compromise Software Supply Chain
Use: During the SolarWinds Compromise, APT29 gained initial network access to some victims via a trojanized update of SolarWinds Orion software.[51][9][13][37]
APT29 has use mshta to execute malicious scripts on a compromised host.[39]
During the SolarWinds Compromise, APT29 used Rundll32.exe to execute payloads.[32][37]
During the SolarWinds Compromise, APT29 used fsutil to check available free space before executing actions that might create large files on disk.[37]

Full_Technique_Name: System Network Configuration Discovery: Internet Connection Discovery
Use: APT29 has ensured web servers in a victim environment are Internet accessible before copying tools or malware to it.[27]During the SolarWinds Compromise, APT29 used GoldFinder to perform HTTP GET requests to check internet connectivity and identify HTTP proxy servers and other redirectors that an HTTP request travels through.[10]

APT29 has compromised IT, cloud services, and managed services providers to gain broad access to multiple customers for subsequent operations.[31]During the SolarWinds Compromise, APT29 gained access through compromised accounts at cloud solution partners, and used compromised certificates issued by Mimecast to authenticate to Mimecast customer systems.[13][24]

During the SolarWinds Compromise, APT29 obtained PKI keys, certificate files, and the private encryption key from an Active Directory Federation Services (AD FS) container to decrypt corresponding SAML signing certificates.[44][13]

Full_Technique_Name: Use Alternate Authentication Material: Application Access Token
Use: During the SolarWinds Compromise, APT29 used compromised service principals to make changes to the Office 365 environment.[24]

Full_Technique_Name: Use Alternate Authentication Material: Pass the Ticket
Use: APT29 used Kerberos ticket attacks for lateral movement.[30]

Full_Technique_Name: Use Alternate Authentication Material: Web Session Cookie
Use: During the SolarWinds Compromise, APT29 used stolen cookies to access cloud resources and a forged duo-sid cookie to bypass MFA set on an email account.[12][24]
APT29 has used various forms of spearphishing attempting to get a user to click on a malicious link.[18][48]
APT29 has used various forms of spearphishing attempting to get a user to open attachments, including, but not limited to, malicious Microsoft Word documents, .pdf, and .lnk files. [3][39][16]

APT29 has used a compromised account to access an organization's VPN infrastructure.[33]During the SolarWinds Compromise, APT29 used different compromised credentials for remote access and to move laterally.[9][10][13]

During the SolarWinds Compromise, APT29 used domain administrators' accounts to help facilitate lateral movement on compromised networks.[24]For Operation Ghost, APT29 used stolen administrator credentials for lateral movement on compromised networks.[22]

APT29 targets dormant or inactive user accounts, accounts belonging to individuals no longer at the organization but whose accounts remain on the system, for access and persistence.[34]During the SolarWinds Compromise, APT29 used compromised local accounts to access victims' networks.[24]

APT29 has gained access to a global administrator account in Azure AD and has used Service Principal credentials in Exchange.[33][27]During the SolarWinds Compromise, APT29 used a compromised O365 administrator account to create a new Service Principal.[24]
For Operation Ghost, APT29 used social media platforms to hide communications to C2 servers.[22]
APT29 used WMI to steal credentials and execute backdoors at a future time.[30]During the SolarWinds Compromise, APT29 used WMI for the remote execution of files for lateral movement.[44][37]
APT3 has used a tool that can obtain info about local and global group users, power users, and administrators.[4]

Full_Technique_Name: Account Manipulation: Additional Local or Domain Groups
Use: APT3 has been known to add created accounts to local admin groups to maintain elevated access.[6]

Full_Technique_Name: Archive Collected Data: Archive via Utility
Use: APT3 has used tools to compress data before exfilling it.[6]

Full_Technique_Name: Boot or Logon Autostart Execution: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
Use: APT3 places scripts in the startup folder for persistence.[3]
APT3 has been known to brute force password hashes to be able to leverage plain text credentials.[7]
APT3 has used PowerShell on victim systems to download and run payloads after exploitation.[3]

Full_Technique_Name: Command and Scripting Interpreter: Windows Command Shell
Use: An APT3 downloader uses the Windows command "cmd.exe" /C whoami. The group also uses a tool to execute commands on remote computers.[3][4]
APT3 has been known to create or enable accounts, such as support_388945a0.[6]

Full_Technique_Name: Create or Modify System Process: Windows Service
Use: APT3 has a tool that creates a new service for persistence.[3]

Full_Technique_Name: Credentials from Password Stores: Credentials from Web Browsers
Use: APT3 has used tools to dump passwords from browsers.[4]
APT3 will identify Microsoft Office documents on the victim's computer.[6]
APT3 has been known to stage files for exfiltration in a single location.[6]
APT3 replaces the Sticky Keys binary C:\Windows\System32\sethc.exe for persistence.[6]
APT3 has a tool that exfiltrates data over the C2 channel.[8]
APT3 has exploited the Adobe Flash Player vulnerability CVE-2015-3113 and Internet Explorer vulnerability CVE-2014-1776.[1][8]
APT3 has a tool that looks for files and directories on the local file system.[8][9]
APT3 has been known to use -WindowStyle Hidden to conceal PowerShell windows.[3]
APT3 has been known to side load DLLs with a valid version of Chrome with one of their tools.[8][10]
APT3 has a tool that can delete files.[8]
APT3 has a tool that can copy files to remote machines.[8]
APT3 has used a keylogging tool that records keystrokes in encrypted files.[4]
APT3 has been known to create or enable accounts, such as support_388945a0.[6]

An APT3 downloader first establishes a SOCKS5 connection to 192.157.198[.]103 using TCP port 1913; once the server response is verified, it then requests a connection to 192.184.60[.]229 on TCP port 81.[3]
An APT3 downloader establishes SOCKS5 connections for its initial C2.[3]
APT3 obfuscates files or information to help evade defensive measures.[4]
APT3 has been known to pack their tools.[7][1]
APT3 has been known to remove indicators of compromise from tools.[7]
APT3 has used a tool to dump credentials by injecting itself into lsass.exe and triggering with the argument "dig."[4]
APT3 has a tool that can enumerate the permissions associated with Windows groups.[4]
APT3 has sent spearphishing emails containing malicious links.[1]
APT3 has a tool that can list out currently running processes.[8][9]
An APT3 downloader establishes SOCKS5 connections for its initial C2.[3]
APT3 enables the Remote Desktop Protocol for persistence.[6] APT3 has also interacted with compromised systems to browse and copy files through RDP sessions.[11]
APT3 will copy files over to Windows Admin Shares (like ADMIN$) as part of lateral movement.[4]
APT3 has a tool that can detect the existence of remote systems.[4][8]
An APT3 downloader creates persistence by creating the following scheduled task: schtasks /create /tn "mysc" /tr C:\Users\Public\test.exe /sc ONLOGON /ru "System".[3]
APT3 has a tool that can run DLLs.[8]
APT3 has a tool that can obtain information about the local system.[4][9]
A keylogging tool used by APT3 gathers network information from the victim, including the MAC address, IP address, WINS, DHCP server, and gateway.[4][9]
APT3 has a tool that can enumerate current network connections.[4][8][9]
An APT3 downloader uses the Windows command "cmd.exe" /C whoami to verify that it is running with the elevated privileges of "System."[3]
APT3 has a tool that can locate credentials in files on the file system such as those from Firefox or Chrome.[4]
APT3 has lured victims into clicking malicious links delivered through spearphishing.[1]
APT3 leverages valid accounts after gaining credentials for use within the victim domain.[4]
APT30 has used spearphishing emails with malicious DOC attachments.[1]
APT30 has relied on users to execute malicious file attachments delivered via spearphishing emails.[1]
APT32 enumerated administrative users using the commands net localgroup administrators.[8]
APT32 has set up and operated websites to gather information and deliver malware.[9]
APT32 has set up Dropbox, Amazon S3, and Google Drive to host malicious downloads.[9]
APT32 has used JavaScript that communicates over HTTP or HTTPS to attacker controlled domains to download additional frameworks. The group has also used downloaded encrypted payloads over HTTP.[2][8]
APT32 has used email for C2 via an Office macro.[4][8]
APT32's backdoor has used LZMA compression and RC4 encryption before exfiltration.[5]

Full_Technique_Name: Boot or Logon Autostart Execution: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
Use: APT32 established persistence using Registry Run keys, both to execute PowerShell and VBS scripts as well as to execute their backdoor directly.[4][8][5]
APT32 has used COM scriptlets to download Cobalt Strike beacons.[8]
APT32 has used PowerShell-based tools, PowerShell one-liners, and shellcode loaders for execution.[1][4][8]
APT32 has used cmd.exe for execution.[8]
APT32 has used macros, COM scriptlets, and VBS scripts.[4][8]
APT32 has used JavaScript for drive-by downloads and C2 communications.[8][9]

Full_Technique_Name: Create or Modify System Process: Windows Service
Use: APT32 modified Windows Services to ensure PowerShell scripts were loaded on the system. APT32 also creates a Windows service to establish persistence.[3][8][5]
APT32 has infected victims by tricking them into visiting compromised watering hole websites.[3][9]
APT32 has set up Facebook pages in tandem with fake websites.[9]

Full_Technique_Name: Exfiltration Over Alternative Protocol: Exfiltration Over Unencrypted Non-C2 Protocol
Use: APT32's backdoor can exfiltrate data by encoding it in the subdomain field of DNS packets.[5]
APT32's backdoor has exfiltrated data using the already opened channel with its C&C server.[5]
APT32 has used RTF document that includes an exploit to execute malicious code. (CVE-2017-11882)[5]
APT32 has used CVE-2016-7255 to escalate privileges.[1]
APT32's backdoor possesses the capability to list files and directories on a machine. [5]

Sub_Technique_Name: Linux and Mac File and Directory Permissions Modification
Full_Technique_Name: File and Directory Permissions Modification: Linux and Mac File and Directory Permissions Modification
Use: APT32's macOS backdoor changes the permission of the file it wants to execute to 755.[10]
APT32 has conducted targeted surveillance against activists and bloggers.[6]
APT32 has collected e-mail addresses for activists and bloggers in order to target them with spyware.[6]

Full_Technique_Name: Hide Artifacts: Hidden Files and Directories
Use: APT32's macOS backdoor hides the clientID file via a chflags function.[10]
APT32 has used the WindowStyle parameter to conceal PowerShell windows. [1] [8]
APT32 used NTFS alternate data streams to hide their payloads.[8]

APT32 ran legitimately-signed executables from Symantec and McAfee which load a malicious DLL. The group also side-loads its backdoor by dropping a library and a legitimate, signed executable (AcroTranscoder).[4][8][5]

Full_Technique_Name: Indicator Removal: Clear Windows Event Logs
Use: APT32 has cleared select event log entries.[1]
APT32's macOS backdoor can receive a "delete" command.[10]

APT32 has used scheduled task raw XML with a backdated timestamp of June 2, 2016. The group has also set the creation time of the files dropped by the second stage of the exploit to match the creation time of kernel32.dll. Additionally, APT32 has used a random value to modify the timestamp of the file storing the clientID.[1][5][10]
APT32 has added JavaScript to victim websites to download additional frameworks that profile and compromise website visitors.[2]
APT32 has abused the PasswordChangeNotify to monitor for and capture account password changes.[8]
APT32 has deployed tools after moving laterally using administrative accounts.[8]
APT32 has disguised a Cobalt Strike beacon as a Flash Installer.[8]
APT32 has moved and renamed pubprn.vbs to a .txt file to avoid detection.[11]

APT32 has used hidden or non-printing characters to help masquerade service names, such as appending a Unicode no-break space character to a legitimate service name. APT32 has also impersonated the legitimate Flash installer file name "install_flashplayer.exe".[1]
APT32 has renamed a NetCat binary to kb-10233.exe to masquerade as a Windows update. APT32 has also renamed a Cobalt Strike beacon payload to install_flashplayers.exe. [8][9]
APT32's backdoor has modified the Windows Registry to store the backdoor's configuration. [5]
APT32 performed network scanning on the network to search for open ports, services, OS finger-printing, and other vulnerabilities.[8]
APT32 used the net view command to show all shares available, including the administrative shares such as C$ and ADMIN$.[8]
An APT32 backdoor can use HTTP over a non-standard TCP port (e.g 14146) which is specified in the backdoor configuration.[5]

Full_Technique_Name: Obfuscated Files or Information: Binary Padding
Use: APT32 includes garbage code to mislead anti-malware software and researchers.[3][5]

Full_Technique_Name: Obfuscated Files or Information: Command Obfuscation
Use: APT32 has used the Invoke-Obfuscation framework to obfuscate their PowerShell.[1][12][8]

Full_Technique_Name: Obfuscated Files or Information: Fileless Storage
Use: APT32's backdoor has stored its configuration in a registry key.[5]

Full_Technique_Name: Obfuscated Files or Information: Encrypted/Encoded File
Use: APT32 has performed code obfuscation, including encoding payloads using Base64 and using a framework called "Dont-Kill-My-Cat (DKMC). APT32 also encrypts the library used for network exfiltration with AES-256 in CBC mode in their macOS backdoor.[1][12][3][4][8][5][10]
APT32 has obtained and used tools such as Mimikatz and Cobalt Strike, and a variety of other open-source tools from GitHub.[1][4]
APT32 have replaced Microsoft Outlook's VbaProject.OTM file to install a backdoor macro for persistence.[4][8]
APT32 used GetPassword_x64 to harvest credentials.[4][8]
APT32 used Mimikatz and customized versions of Windows Credential Dumper to harvest credentials.[4][8]
APT32 has sent spearphishing emails with a malicious executable disguised as a document or spreadsheet.[3][4][8][5][13][6]
APT32 has sent spearphishing emails containing malicious links.[3][4][13][9][6]
APT32 has used malicious links to direct users to web pages designed to harvest credentials.[9]
APT32 malware has injected a Cobalt Strike beacon into Rundll32.exe.[8]
APT32's backdoor can query the Windows Registry to gather system information. [5]
APT32 used Net to use Windows' hidden network shares to copy their tools to remote machines for execution.[8]
APT32 has enumerated DC servers using the command net group "Domain Controllers" /domain. The group has also used the ping command.[8]
APT32 has used scheduled tasks to persist on victim systems.[1][4][8][5]
APT32 has used Web shells to maintain access to victim websites.[2]
APT32 compromised McAfee ePO to move laterally by distributing malware as a software deployment task.[1]
APT32 has hosted malicious payloads in Dropbox, Amazon S3, and Google Drive for use during targeting.[9]

APT32 has stood up websites containing numerous articles and content scraped from the Internet to make them appear legitimate, but some of these pages include malicious JavaScript to profile the potential victim or infect them via a fake software update.[9]
APT32 has used mshta.exe for code execution.[4][8]

APT32 created a Scheduled Task/Job that used regsvr32.exe to execute a COM scriptlet that dynamically downloaded a backdoor and injected it into memory. The group has also used regsvr32 to run their backdoor.[5][1][8]

APT41 sent spearphishing emails with attachments such as compiled HTML (.chm) files to initially compromise their victims.[2]
APT41 deployed Master Boot Record bootkits on Windows systems to hide their malware and maintain persistence on victim systems.[2]
APT41 malware TIDYELF loaded the main WINTERLOVE component by injecting it into the iexplore.exe process.[2]
APT41 used a tool called CLASSFON to covertly proxy network communications.[2]During C0017, APT41 used the Cloudflare CDN to proxy C2 traffic.[7]
APT41 queried registry values to determine items such as configured RDP ports and network configurations.[8]
APT41 used RDP for lateral movement.[2][4] APT41 used NATBypass to expose local RDP ports on compromised systems to the Internet.[10]
APT41 has transferred implant files using Windows Admin Shares and the Server Message Block (SMB) protocol, then executes files through Windows Management Instrumentation (WMI).[4][10]
APT41 has used MiPing to discover active systems in the victim network.[10]
APT41 deployed a Monero cryptocurrency mining tool in a victim’s environment.[2][1]
APT41 deployed rootkits on Linux systems.[2][4]

APT41 used a compromised account to create a scheduled task on a system.[2][4]During C0017, APT41 used the following Windows scheduled tasks for DEADEYE dropper persistence on US state government networks: \Microsoft\Windows\PLA\Server Manager Performance Monitor, \Microsoft\Windows\Ras\ManagerMobility, \Microsoft\Windows\WDI\SrvSetupResults, and \Microsoft\Windows\WDI\USOShared.[7]

Full_Technique_Name: Search Open Technical Databases: Scan Databases
Use: APT41 uses the Chinese website fofa.su, similar to the Shodan scanning service, for passive scanning of victims.[8]APT41 DUST used internet scan data for target development.[6]
APT41 DUST involved use of search engines to research victim servers.[6]
APT41 DUST involved access of external victim websites for target development.[6]
APT41 DUST involved use of web shells such as ANTSWORD and BLUEBEAM for persistence.[6]During C0017, APT41 deployed JScript web shells through the creation of malicious ViewState objects.[7]

APT41 leveraged code-signing certificates to sign malware when targeting both gaming and non-gaming organizations.[2][3]APT41 DUST used stolen code signing certificates for DUSTTRAP malware and subsequent payloads.[6]

Full_Technique_Name: Supply Chain Compromise: Compromise Software Supply Chain
Use: APT41 gained access to production environments where they could inject malicious code into legitimate, signed files and widely distribute them to end users.[2]

Full_Technique_Name: System Binary Proxy Execution: Compiled HTML File
Use: APT41 used compiled HTML (.chm) files for targeting.[2]
APT41 has used rundll32.exe to execute a loader.[4]

APT41 uses multiple built-in commands such as systeminfo and net config Workstation to enumerate victim system basic configuration information.[8]During C0017, APT41 issued ping -n 1 ((cmd /c dir c:\|findstr Number).split()[-1]+ commands to find the volume serial number of compromised systems.[7]
APT41 collected MAC addresses from victim machines.[2][3] During C0017, APT41 used cmd.exe /c ping %userdomain% for discovery.[7]

APT41 has enumerated IP addresses of network resources and used the netstat command as part of network reconnaissance. The group has also used a malware variant, HIGHNOON, to enumerate active RDP sessions.[2][3]
APT41 has executed whoami commands, including using the WMIEXEC utility to execute this on remote machines.[2][8]During C0017, APT41 used whoami to gather information from victim machines.[7]
APT41 used  svchost.exe and Net to execute a system service installed to launch a Cobalt Strike BEACON loader.[9][3]APT41 DUST used Windows services to execute DUSTPAN.[6]

Full_Technique_Name: Use Alternate Authentication Material: Pass the Hash
Use: APT41 uses tools such as Mimikatz to enable lateral movement via captured password hashes.[8]
APT41 used compromised credentials to log on to other systems.[2][4]

APT41 used legitimate websites for C2 through dead drop resolvers (DDR), including GitHub, Pastebin, and Microsoft TechNet.[2]During C0017, APT41 used dead drop resolvers on two separate tech community forums for their KEYPLUG Windows-version backdoor; notably APT41 updated the community forum posts frequently with new dead drop resolvers during the campaign.[7]

APT41 used WMI in several ways, including for execution of commands via WMIEXEC as well as for persistence via PowerSploit.[2][3] APT41 has executed files through Windows Management Instrumentation (WMI).[10]

Use: APT5 has used the JAR/ZIP file format for exfiltrated files.[4]
APT5 has used PowerShell to accomplish tasks within targeted environments.[4]

Full_Technique_Name: Command and Scripting Interpreter: Windows Command Shell
Use: APT5 has used cmd.exe for execution on compromised systems.[4]
APT5 has modified legitimate binaries and scripts for Pulse Secure VPNs including the legitimate DSUpgrade.pm file to install the ATRIUM webshell for persistence.[3][4]
APT5 has created Local Administrator accounts to maintain access to systems with short-cycle credential rotation.[4]
APT5 has staged data on compromised systems prior to exfiltration often in C:\Users\Public.[4]

APT5 has used the BLOODMINE utility to discover files with .css, .jpg, .png, .gif, .ico, .js, and .jsp extensions in Pulse Secure Connect logs.[4]
APT5 has used the CLEANPULSE utility to insert command line strings into a targeted process to prevent certain log events from occurring.[4]
APT5 has used the THINBLOOD utility to clear SSL VPN log files located at /home/runtime/logs.[3][4]
APT5 has cleared the command history on targeted ESXi servers.[4]
APT5 has deleted scripts and web shells to evade detection.[3][4]
APT5 has modified file timestamps.[4]
APT5 has used malware with keylogging capabilities to monitor the communications of targeted entities.[5][6]
APT5 has used the BLOODMINE utility to parse and extract information from Pulse Secure Connect logs.[4]

Full_Technique_Name: Masquerading: Match Legitimate Name or Location
Use: APT5 has named exfiltration archives to mimic Windows Updates at times using filenames with a KB<digits>.zip pattern.[4]

APT5 has used the Task Manager process to target LSASS process memory in order to obtain NTLM password hashes. APT5 has also dumped clear text passwords and hashes from memory using Mimikatz hosted through an RDP mapped drive.[4]

Full_Technique_Name: OS Credential Dumping: Security Account Manager
Use: APT5 has copied and exfiltrated the SAM Registry hive from targeted systems.[4]
APT5 has used Windows-based utilities to carry out tasks including tasklist.exe. [4]
APT5 has used the CLEANPULSE utility to insert command line strings into a targeted process to alter its functionality.[4]
APT5 has moved laterally throughout victim environments using RDP.[4]
APT5 has used SSH for lateral movement in compromised environments including for enabling access to ESXi host servers.[4]
APT5 has made modifications to the crontab file including in /var/cron/tabs/.[1]
APT5 has installed multiple web shells on compromised servers including on Pulse Secure VPN appliances.[3][4]
APT5 has used the BLOODMINE utility to collect data on web requests from Pulse Secure Connect logs.[4]
APT5 has used legitimate account credentials to move laterally through compromised environments.[3]
APT5 has accessed Microsoft M365 cloud environments using stolen credentials. [4]
Aquatic Panda used the last command in Linux environments to identify recently logged-in users on victim machines.[2]
Aquatic Panda has used publicly accessible DNS logging services to identify servers vulnerable to Log4j (CVE 2021-44228).[1]

Full_Technique_Name: Archive Collected Data: Archive via Utility
Use: Aquatic Panda has used several publicly available tools, including WinRAR and 7zip, to compress collected files and memory dumps prior to exfiltration.[1][2]
Aquatic Panda has downloaded additional scripts and executed Base64 encoded commands in PowerShell.[1]

Full_Technique_Name: Command and Scripting Interpreter: Windows Command Shell
Use: Aquatic Panda has attempted and failed to run Bash commands on a Windows host by passing them to cmd /C.[1]

Full_Technique_Name: Command and Scripting Interpreter: Unix Shell
Use: Aquatic Panda used malicious shell scripts in Linux environments following access via SSH to install Linux versions of Winnti malware.[2]

Full_Technique_Name: Create or Modify System Process: Windows Service
Use: Aquatic Panda created new Windows services for persistence that masqueraded as legitimate Windows services via name change.[2]
Aquatic Panda captured local Windows security event log data from victim machines using the wevtutil utility to extract contents to an evtx output file.[2]

Full_Technique_Name: Hijack Execution Flow: DLL Search Order Hijacking
Use: Aquatic Panda has used DLL search-order hijacking to load exe, dll, and dat files into memory.[1] Aquatic Panda loaded a malicious DLL into the legitimate Windows Security Health Service executable (SecurityHealthService.exe) to execute malicious code on victim systems.[2]

Full_Technique_Name: Hijack Execution Flow: Dynamic Linker Hijacking
Use: Aquatic Panda modified the ld.so preload file in Linux environments to enable persistence for Winnti malware.[2]

Full_Technique_Name: Impair Defenses: Disable or Modify Tools
Use: Aquatic Panda has attempted to stop endpoint detection and response (EDR) tools on compromised systems.[1]

Full_Technique_Name: Indicator Removal: Clear Windows Event Logs
Use: Aquatic Panda clears Windows Event Logs following activity to evade defenses.[2]
Aquatic Panda cleared command history in Linux environments to remove traces of activity after operations.[2]
Aquatic Panda has deleted malicious executables from compromised machines.[1][2]
Aquatic Panda has downloaded additional malware onto compromised hosts.[1]
Aquatic Panda enumerated logs related to authentication in Linux environments prior to deleting selective entries for defense evasion purposes.[2]
Aquatic Panda created new, malicious services using names such as Windows User Service to attempt to blend in with legitimate items on victim systems.[2]

Full_Technique_Name: Masquerading: Match Legitimate Name or Location
Use: Aquatic Panda renamed or moved malicious binaries to legitimate locations to evade defenses and blend into victim environments.[2]
Aquatic Panda modified the victim registry to enable the RestrictedAdmin mode feature, allowing for pass the hash behaviors to function via RDP.[2]

Full_Technique_Name: Obfuscated Files or Information: Command Obfuscation
Use: Aquatic Panda has encoded PowerShell commands in Base64.[1]
Aquatic Panda has acquired and used njRAT in its operations.[1]
Aquatic Panda has acquired and used Cobalt Strike in its operations.[1]
Aquatic Panda has attempted to harvest credentials through LSASS memory dumping.[1]
Aquatic Panda used remote scheduled tasks to install malicious software on victim systems during lateral movement actions.[2]
Aquatic Panda leveraged stolen credentials to move laterally via RDP in victim environments.[2]
Aquatic Panda used remote shares to enable lateral movement in victim environments.[2]
Aquatic Panda used SSH with captured user credentials to move laterally in victim environments.[2]
Aquatic Panda has attempted to discover third party endpoint detection and response (EDR) tools on compromised systems.[1]
Aquatic Panda used rundll32.exe to proxy execution of a malicious DLL file identified as a keylogging binary.[2]
Aquatic Panda has used native OS commands to understand privilege levels and system details.[1]
Aquatic Panda gathers information on recently logged-in users on victim devices.[2]
Aquatic Panda has attempted to discover services for third party EDR products.[1]

Full_Technique_Name: Use Alternate Authentication Material: Pass the Hash
Use: Aquatic Panda used a registry edit to enable a Windows feature called RestrictedAdmin in victim environments. This change allowed Aquatic Panda to leverage "pass the hash" mechanisms as the alteration allows for RDP connections with a valid account name and hash only, without possessing a cleartext password value.[2]
Aquatic Panda used multiple mechanisms to capture valid user accounts for victim domains to enable lateral movement and access to additional hosts in victim environments.[2]
Aquatic Panda used WMI for lateral movement in victim environments.[2]

Blue Mockingbird has used wmic.exe to set environment variables.[1]

Use: BRONZE BUTLER has used batch scripts and the command-line interface for execution.[2]

BRONZE BUTLER has used a tool to capture screenshots.[2][3]
BRONZE BUTLER has used tools to enumerate software installed on an infected host.[3]

Full_Technique_Name: Modify Authentication Process: Domain Controller Authentication
Use: Chimera's malware has altered the NTLM authentication program on domain controllers to allow Chimera to login without a valid credential.[1]
Chimera has registered alternate phone numbers for compromised users to intercept 2FA codes sent via SMS.[2]
Chimera has used direct Windows system calls by leveraging Dumpert.[1]
Chimera has used the get -b  -e  -p command for network scanning as well as a custom Python tool  packed into a Windows executable named Get.exe to scan IP ranges for HTTP.[2]
Chimera has used net share and net view to identify network shares of interest.[2]

Full_Technique_Name: Obfuscated Files or Information: Command Obfuscation
Use: Chimera has encoded PowerShell commands.[1]
Chimera has obtained and used tools such as BloodHound, Cobalt Strike, Mimikatz, and PsExec.[1][2]

Chimera has gathered the SYSTEM registry and ntds.dit files from target systems.[1] Chimera specifically has used the NtdsAudit tool to dump the password hashes of domain users via msadcs.exe "NTDS.dit" -s "SYSTEM" -p RecordedTV_pdmp.txt --users-csv RecordedTV_users.csv and used ntdsutil to copy the Active Directory database.[2]
Chimera has used the NtdsAudit utility to collect information related to accounts and passwords.[2]
Chimera has used net localgroup administrators to identify  accounts with local administrative rights.[2]
Chimera has used tasklist to enumerate processes.[2]
Chimera has encapsulated Cobalt Strike's C2 protocol in DNS and HTTPS.[2]
Chimera has queried Registry keys using reg query \\HKU\\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Terminal Server Client\Servers and reg query \\HKU\\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Internet Settings.[2]
Chimera has used RDP to access targeted systems.[1]
Chimera has used Windows admin shares to move laterally.[1][2]
Chimera has used WinRM for lateral movement.[2]
Chimera has utilized various scans and queries to find domain controllers and remote services in the target environment.[2]

Chimera has used scheduled tasks to invoke Cobalt Strike including through batch script schtasks /create /ru "SYSTEM" /tn "update" /tr "cmd /c c:\windows\temp\update.bat" /sc once /f /st and to maintain persistence.[1][2]
Chimera has used fsutil fsinfo drives, systeminfo, and vssadmin list shadows for system information including shadow volumes and drive information.[2]
Chimera has used ipconfig, Ping, and tracert to enumerate the IP address and network environment and settings of the local host.[2]
Chimera has used netstat -ano | findstr EST to discover network connections.[2]
Chimera has used the quser command to show currently logged on users.[2]
Chimera has used net start and net use for system service discovery.[2]
Chimera has used PsExec to deploy beacons on compromised systems.[2]
Chimera has used time /t and net time \ip/hostname for system time discovery.[2]

Full_Technique_Name: Use Alternate Authentication Material: Pass the Hash
Use: Chimera has dumped password hashes for use in pass the hash authentication attacks.[2]
Chimera has used a valid account to maintain persistence via scheduled task.[1]
Chimera has used compromised domain accounts to gain access to the target environment.[2]
Chimera has used WMIC to execute remote commands.[1][2]
Cinnamon Tempest has used PowerShell to communicate with C2, download files, and execute reconnaissance commands.[5]

Use: Cinnamon Tempest has executed ransomware using batch scripts deployed via GPO.[1]

Use: Cinnamon Tempest has created system services to establish persistence for deployed tooling.[5]
Cinnamon Tempest has used weaponized DLLs to load and decrypt payloads.[5]

Use: Cinnamon Tempest has used Group Policy to deploy batch scripts for ransomware deployment.[1]

Full_Technique_Name: Exfiltration Over Web Service: Exfiltration to Cloud Storage
Use: Cinnamon Tempest has uploaded captured keystroke logs to the Alibaba Cloud Object Storage Service, Aliyun OSS.[5]

Cinnamon Tempest has exploited multiple unpatched vulnerabilities for initial access including vulnerabilities in Microsoft Exchange, Manage Engine AdSelfService Plus, Confluence, and Log4j.[1][7][5][4]
Cinnamon Tempest has maintained leak sites for exfiltrated data in attempt to extort victims into paying a ransom.[1]

Full_Technique_Name: Hijack Execution Flow: DLL Search Order Hijacking
Use: Cinnamon Tempest has used search order hijacking to launch Cobalt Strike Beacons.[1][4]
Cinnamon Tempest has abused legitimate executables to side-load weaponized DLLs.[5]
Cinnamon Tempest has downloaded files, including Cobalt Strike, to compromised hosts.[5]
Cinnamon Tempest has used open-source tools including customized versions of the Iox proxy tool, NPS tunneling tool, Meterpreter, and a keylogger that uploads data to Alibaba cloud storage.[5][4]
Cinnamon Tempest has used the Iox and NPS proxy and tunneling tools in combination  create multiple connections through a single tunnel.[5]
Cinnamon Tempest has used a customized version of the Iox port-forwarding and proxy tool.[5]
Cinnamon Tempest has used SMBexec for lateral movement.[5]
Cinnamon Tempest has deployed ransomware from a batch file in a network share.[1]
Cinnamon Tempest has used compromised user accounts to deploy payloads and create system services.[5]
Cinnamon Tempest has obtained highly privileged credentials such as domain administrator in order to deploy malware.[1]
Cinnamon Tempest has used Impacket for lateral movement via WMI.[1][5]
Cleaver has used custom tools to facilitate ARP cache poisoning.[1]

Cleaver has created customized tools and payloads for functions including ARP poisoning, encryption, credential dumping, ASP.NET shells, web backdoors, process enumeration, WMI querying, HTTP and SMB communications, network interface sniffing, and keystroke logging.[1]
Cleaver has created fake LinkedIn profiles that included profile photos, details, and connections.[2]
Cleaver has obtained and used open-source tools such as PsExec, Windows Credential Editor, and Mimikatz.[1]
Cleaver has been known to dump credentials using Mimikatz and Windows Credential Editor.[1]

Use: Cobalt Group has bypassed UAC.[4]

Full_Technique_Name: Boot or Logon Initialization Scripts: Logon Script (Windows)
Use: Cobalt Group has added persistence by registering the file name for the next stage malware under HKCU\Environment\UserInitMprLogonScript.[11]
Cobalt Group has used powershell.exe to download and execute scripts.[1][2][3][4][7][12]

Use: Cobalt Group has used a JavaScript backdoor that is capable of launching cmd.exe to execute shell commands.[11] The group has used an exploit toolkit known as Threadkit that launches .bat files.[1][2][4][11][13][12]

Full_Technique_Name: Command and Scripting Interpreter: Visual Basic
Use: Cobalt Group has sent Word OLE compound documents with malicious obfuscated VBA macros that will run upon user execution.[1][2][4][11][13][12]
Cobalt Group has executed JavaScript scriptlets on the victim's machine.[1][2][4][11][13][12]

Full_Technique_Name: Create or Modify System Process: Windows Service
Use: Cobalt Group has created new services to establish persistence.[4]
Cobalt Group has used the Plink utility to create SSH tunnels.[4]

Cobalt Group had exploited multiple vulnerabilities for execution, including Microsoft’s Equation Editor (CVE-2017-11882), an Internet Explorer vulnerability (CVE-2018-8174), CVE-2017-8570, CVE-2017-0199, and CVE-2017-8759.[1][2][3][5][6][7][10][12]
Cobalt Group has used exploits to increase their levels of rights and privileges.[4]
Cobalt Group deleted the DLL dropper from the victim’s machine to cover their tracks.[1]

Cobalt Group has used public sites such as github.com and sendspace.com to upload files and then download them to victim computers.[2][3] The group's JavaScript backdoor is also capable of downloading files.[11]
Cobalt Group has sent malicious Word OLE compound documents to victims.[1]
Cobalt Group leveraged an open-source tool called SoftPerfect Network Scanner to perform network scanning.[2][3][4]

Full_Technique_Name: Obfuscated Files or Information: Command Obfuscation
Use: Cobalt Group obfuscated several scriptlets and code used on the victim’s machine, including through use of XOR and RC4.[1][11]
Cobalt Group has obtained and used a variety of tools including Mimikatz, PsExec, Cobalt Strike, and SDelete.[3]

Cobalt Group has sent spearphishing emails with various attachment types to corporate and personal email accounts of victim organizations. Attachment types have included .rtf, .doc, .xls, archives containing LNK files, and password protected archives containing .exe and .scr executables.[1][2][3][4][5][6][13][12]
Cobalt Group has sent emails with URLs pointing to malicious documents.[1][9]
Cobalt Group has injected code into trusted processes.[4]
Cobalt Group has used the Plink utility to create SSH tunnels.[1][3][4]
Cobalt Group used the Ammyy Admin tool as well as TeamViewer for remote access, including to preserve remote access if a Cobalt Strike module was lost.[2][3][4]
Cobalt Group has used Remote Desktop Protocol to conduct lateral movement.[4]
Cobalt Group has created Windows tasks to establish persistence.[4]
Cobalt Group used a JavaScript backdoor that is capable of collecting a list of the security solutions installed on the victim's machine.[11]

Full_Technique_Name: Supply Chain Compromise: Compromise Software Supply Chain
Use: Cobalt Group has compromised legitimate web browser updates to deliver a backdoor. [14]
Cobalt Group has used the command cmstp.exe /s /ns C:\Users\ADMINI~W\AppData\Local\Temp\XKNqbpzl.txt to bypass AppLocker and launch a malicious script.[1][11][13]
Cobalt Group has used odbcconf to proxy the execution of malicious DLL files.[12]
Cobalt Group has used regsvr32.exe to execute scripts.[1][11][12]
Cobalt Group has sent emails containing malicious links that require users to execute a file or macro to infect the victim machine.[1][13][9]
Cobalt Group has sent emails containing malicious attachments that require users to execute a file or macro to infect the victim machine.[1][13]
Cobalt Group used msxsl.exe to bypass AppLocker and to invoke Jscript code from an XSL file.[1]

Confucius has downloaded additional files and payloads onto a compromised host following initial access.[3][2]
Confucius has crafted and sent victims malicious attachments to gain initial access.[3]
Confucius has sent malicious links to victims through email campaigns.[2]
Confucius has created scheduled tasks to maintain persistence on a compromised host.[2]
Confucius has used mshta.exe to execute malicious VBScript.[1]
Confucius has used a file stealer that can examine system drives, including those other than the C drive.[2]

Use: CopyKittens uses ZPP, a .NET console program, to compress files with ZIP.[2]

Use: CopyKittens encrypts data with a substitute cipher prior to exfiltration.[3]

CopyKittens uses rundll32 to load various tools on victims, including a lateral movement tool named Vminst, Cobalt Strike, and shellcode.[2]

Sub_Technique_Name: Exfiltration Over Asymmetric Encrypted Non-C2 Protocol

During the Unitronics Defacement Campaign, the CyberAv3ngers discovered and exploited default credentials found on many Unitronics Programmable Logic Controller (PLC) Human-Machine Interface (HMI). For many of these devices, the default password was set to ‘1111’.[1][3]

During the Unitronics Defacement Campaign, the CyberAv3ngers defaced controllers’ Human-Machine Interface (HMI), which prevented multiple entities from being able to operate their devices normally.[1][3][4][5] Additionally, the CyberAv3ngers caused a communications failure in a remote pumping station.[6]

During the Unitronics Defacement Campaign, the CyberAv3ngers exploited devices connected to the public internet, such as internet connected Unitronics Programmable Logic Controller (PLC) with Human-Machine Interface (HMI) and networking equipment such as cellular modems found in OT environments.[1][2]

During the Unitronics Defacement Campaign, the CyberAv3ngers caused multiple businesses to halt operations due to the unavailability of the Programmable Logic Controller (PLC) and Human-Machine Interface (HMI). These victims covered multiple sectors.[4]

During the Unitronics Defacement Campaign, the CyberAv3ngers caused multiple businesses to halt operations in their industrial environments, impacting their typical business operations. These victims covered multiple sectors.[4]

During the Unitronics Defacement Campaign, the CyberAv3ngers replaced the existing graphic on the Programmable Logic Controller (PLC) Human-Machine Interface (HMI) with their own, thereby preventing PLC owners and operators from viewing PLC information on the HMI.[1][4]
Daggerfly uses HTTP for command and control communication.[4]
Daggerfly used PowerShell to download and execute remote-hosted files on victim systems.[1]
Daggerfly compromised web servers hosting updates for software as part of a supply chain intrusion.[4]
Daggerfly created a local account on victim machines to maintain access.[1]
Daggerfly created code signing certificates to sign malicious macOS files.[4]
Daggerfly has used strategic website compromise for initial access against victims.[4]
Daggerfly has used legitimate software to side-load PlugX loaders onto victim systems.[1] Daggerfly is also linked to multiple other instances of side-loading for initial loading activity.[4]
Daggerfly has used PowerShell and BITSAdmin to retrieve follow-on payloads from external locations for execution on victim machines.[1]
Daggerfly used a renamed version of rundll32.exe, such as "dbengin.exe" located in the ProgramData\Microsoft\PlayReady directory, to proxy malicious DLL execution.[1]

Daggerfly has attempted to use scheduled tasks for persistence in victim environments.[4]
Daggerfly has used signed, but not notarized, malicious files for execution in macOS environments.[4]

Full_Technique_Name: Supply Chain Compromise: Compromise Software Supply Chain
Use: Daggerfly is associated with several supply chain compromises using malicious updates to compromise victims.[2][4]
Daggerfly proxied execution of malicious DLLs through a renamed rundll32.exe binary.[1]
Daggerfly utilizes victim machine operating system information to create custom User Agent strings for subsequent command and control communication.[4]
Daggerfly has used strategic website compromise to deliver a malicious link requiring user interaction.[4]

Darkhotel has used malware that searched for files with specific patterns.[6]

Darkhotel malware has used a series of checks to determine if it's being analyzed; checks include the length of executable names, if a filename ends with .Md5.exe, and if the program is executed from the root of the C:\ drive, as well as checks for sandbox-related libraries.[8][4]
Darkhotel has used malware that repeatedly checks the mouse cursor position to determine if a real user is on the system.[8]

Dragonfly has moved laterally via RDP.[15]
Dragonfly has likely obtained a list of hosts in the victim environment.[15]
Dragonfly has used scheduled tasks to automatically log out of created accounts every 8 hours as well as to execute malicious files.[15]
Dragonfly has performed screen captures of victims, including by using a tool, scr.exe (which matched the hash of ScreenUtil).[15][5][7]
Dragonfly has commonly created Web shells on victims' publicly accessible email and web servers, which they used to maintain access to a victim network and download additional malicious files.[15]
Dragonfly has compromised websites to redirect traffic and to host exploit kits.[7]

Full_Technique_Name: Supply Chain Compromise: Compromise Software Supply Chain
Use: Dragonfly has placed trojanized installers for control system software on legitimate vendor app stores.[4][7]
Dragonfly has used batch scripts to enumerate network information, including information about trusts, zones, and the domain.[15]
Dragonfly used the command query user on victim hosts.[15]
Dragonfly has injected SMB URLs into malicious Word spearphishing attachments to initiate Forced Authentication.[15]
Dragonfly has used various forms of spearphishing in attempts to get users to open malicious attachments.[7]
Dragonfly has compromised user credentials and used valid accounts for operations.[15][7][8]
Dragonfly utilized watering hole attacks on energy sector websites by injecting a redirect iframe to deliver Backdoor.Oldrea or Trojan.Karagany. [18]
Dragonfly trojanized legitimate ICS equipment providers software packages available for download on their websites.[18]

Full_Technique_Name: Abuse Elevation Control Mechanism: Bypass User Account Control
Use: Earth Lusca has used the Fodhelper UAC bypass technique to gain elevated privileges.[1]
Earth Lusca has dropped an SSH-authorized key in the /root/.ssh folder in order to access a compromised server with SSH.[1]
Earth Lusca has registered domains, intended to look like legitimate target domains, that have been used in watering hole attacks.[1]
Earth Lusca has acquired multiple servers for some of their operations, using each server for a different role.[1]
Earth Lusca has established GitHub accounts to host their malware.[1]
Earth Lusca has scanned for vulnerabilities in the public-facing servers of their targets.[1]

Full_Technique_Name: Archive Collected Data: Archive via Utility
Use: Earth Lusca has used WinRAR to compress stolen files into an archive prior to exfiltration.[1]

Full_Technique_Name: Boot or Logon Autostart Execution: Print Processors
Use: Earth Lusca has added the Registry key HKLM\SYSTEM\ControlSet001\Control\Print\Environments\Windows x64\Print Processors\UDPrint" /v Driver /d "spool.dll /f to load malware as a Print Processor.[1]
Earth Lusca has used PowerShell to execute commands.[1]

Full_Technique_Name: Command and Scripting Interpreter: Visual Basic
Use: Earth Lusca used VBA scripts.[1]
Earth Lusca used Python scripts for port scanning or building reverse shells.[1]
Earth Lusca has manipulated legitimate websites to inject malicious JavaScript code as part of their watering hole operations.[1]
Earth Lusca has used compromised web servers as part of their operational infrastructure.[1]
Earth Lusca has compromised Google Drive repositories.[1]

Full_Technique_Name: Create or Modify System Process: Windows Service
Use: Earth Lusca created a service using the command sc create "SysUpdate" binpath= "cmd /c start "[file path]""&&sc config "SysUpdate" start= auto&&netstart SysUpdate for persistence.[1]
Earth Lusca has used certutil to decode a string into a cabinet file.[1]
Earth Lusca has used Nltest to obtain information about domain controllers.[1]
Earth Lusca has performed watering hole attacks.[1]

Full_Technique_Name: Exfiltration Over Web Service: Exfiltration to Cloud Storage
Use: Earth Lusca has used the megacmd tool to upload stolen files from a victim network to MEGA.[1]
Earth Lusca has compromised victims by directly exploiting vulnerabilities of public-facing servers, including those associated with Microsoft Exchange and Oracle GlassFish.[1]
Earth Lusca has used Mimikatz to exploit a domain controller via the ZeroLogon exploit (CVE-2020-1472).[1]
Earth Lusca has placed a malicious payload in %WINDIR%\SYSTEM32\oci.dll so it would be sideloaded by the MSDTC service.[1]

Full_Technique_Name: Masquerading: Match Legitimate Name or Location
Use: Earth Lusca used the command move [file path] c:\windows\system32\spool\prtprocs\x64\spool.dll to move and register a malicious DLL name as a Windows print processor, which eventually was loaded by the Print Spooler service.[1]
Earth Lusca modified the registry using the command reg add "HKEY_CURRENT_USER\Environment" /v UserInitMprLogonScript /t REG_SZ /d "[file path]" for persistence.[1]
Earth Lusca used Base64 to encode strings.[1]
Earth Lusca has used steganography to hide shellcode in a BMP image file.[1]
Earth Lusca has acquired and used a variety of malware, including Cobalt Strike.[1]
Earth Lusca has acquired and used a variety of open source tools.[1]
Earth Lusca has used ProcDump to obtain the hashes of credentials by dumping the memory of the LSASS process.[1]
Earth Lusca has used a DCSync command with Mimikatz to retrieve credentials from an exploited controller.[1]
Earth Lusca has sent spearphishing emails to potential targets that contained a malicious link.[1]
Earth Lusca has used Tasklist to obtain information from a compromised host.[1]
Earth Lusca adopted Cloudflare as a proxy for compromised servers.[1]

Earth Lusca used the command powershell "Get-EventLog -LogName security -Newest 500 | where {$_.EventID -eq 4624} | format-list -property * | findstr "Address"" to find the network information of successfully logged-in accounts to discovery addresses of other machines. Earth Lusca has also used multiple scanning tools to discover other machines within the same compromised network.[1]
Earth Lusca used the command schtasks /Create /SC ONLOgon /TN WindowsUpdateCheck /TR "[file path]" /ru system for persistence.[1]
Earth Lusca has staged malware and malicious files on compromised web servers, GitHub, and Google Drive.[1]
Earth Lusca has used mshta.exe to load an HTA script within a malicious .LNK file.[1]
Earth Lusca used the command ipconfig to obtain information about network configurations.[1]

Earth Lusca employed a PowerShell script called RDPConnectionParser to read and filter the Windows event log "Microsoft-Windows-TerminalServices-RDPClient/Operational"(Event ID 1024) to obtain network information from RDP connections. Earth Lusca has also used netstat from a compromised system to obtain network connection information.[1]
Earth Lusca collected information on user accounts via the whoami command.[1]
Earth Lusca has used Tasklist to obtain information from a compromised host.[1]
Earth Lusca  has sent spearphishing emails that required the user to click on a malicious link and subsequently open a decoy document with a malicious loader.[1]
Earth Lusca required users to click on a malicious file for the loader to activate.[1]
Earth Lusca used a VBA script to execute WMI.[1]
Elderwood has delivered zero-day exploits and malware to victims by injecting malicious code into specific public Web pages visited by targets within a particular sector.[2][3][1]
Elderwood has used exploitation of endpoint software, including Microsoft Internet Explorer Adobe Flash vulnerabilities, to gain execution. They have also used zero-day exploits.[2]
The Ritsol backdoor trojan used by Elderwood can download files onto a compromised host from a remote location.[4]

Full_Technique_Name: Obfuscated Files or Information: Software Packing
Use: Elderwood has packed malware payloads before delivery to victims.[2]

Full_Technique_Name: Obfuscated Files or Information: Encrypted/Encoded File
Use: Elderwood has encrypted documents and malicious executables.[2]
Elderwood has delivered zero-day exploits and malware to victims via targeted emails containing malicious attachments.[2][3]
Elderwood has delivered zero-day exploits and malware to victims via targeted emails containing a link to malicious content hosted on an uncommon Web server.[2][3]
Elderwood has leveraged multiple types of spearphishing in order to attempt to get a user to open links.[2][3]
Elderwood has leveraged multiple types of spearphishing in order to attempt to get a user to open attachments.[2][3]
Ember Bear uses services such as IVPN, SurfShark, and Tor to add anonymization to operations.[2]
Ember Bear has used virtual private servers (VPSs) to host tools, perform reconnaissance, exploit victim infrastructure, and as a destination for data exfiltration.[1]
Ember Bear has targeted IP ranges for vulnerability scanning related to government and critical infrastructure organizations.[1]
Ember Bear has used publicly available tools such as MASSCAN and Acunetix for vulnerability scanning of public-facing infrastructure.[1]
Ember Bear has used DNS tunnelling tools, such as dnscat/2 and Iodine, for C2 purposes.[1]
Ember Bear has compressed collected data prior to exfiltration.[1]
Ember Bear engages in mass collection from compromised systems during intrusions.[2]
Ember Bear used the su-bruteforce tool to brute force specific users using the su command.[1]
Ember Bear has conducted password spraying against Outlook Web Access (OWA) infrastructure to identify valid user names and passwords.[1]
Ember Bear has used PowerShell commands to gather information from compromised systems,  such as email servers.[1]
Ember Bear gathers victim system information such as enumerating the volume of a given device or extracting system and security event logs for analysis.[2][1]
Ember Bear is linked to the defacement of several Ukrainian organization websites.[2]
Ember Bear conducted destructive operations against victims, including disk structure wiping, via the WhisperGate malware in Ukraine.[2]
Ember Bear attempts to collect mail from accessed systems and servers.[2][1]
Ember Bear has created accounts on dark web forums to obtain various tools and malware.[1]

Full_Technique_Name: Exfiltration Over Web Service: Exfiltration to Cloud Storage
Use: Ember Bear has used tools such as Rclone to exfiltrate information from victim environments to cloud storage such as mega.nz.[1]

Ember Bear gains initial access to victim environments by exploiting external-facing services. Examples include exploitation of CVE-2021-26084 in Confluence servers; CVE-2022-41040, ProxyShell, and other vulnerabilities in Microsoft Exchange; and multiple vulnerabilities in open-source platforms such as content management systems.[2][1]
Ember Bear has used exploits to enable follow-on execution of frameworks such as Meterpreter.[1]
Ember Bear has used exploits for vulnerabilities such as MS17-010, also known as Eternal Blue, during operations.[1]
Ember Bear have used VPNs both for initial access to victim environments and for persistence within them following compromise.[1]

Full_Technique_Name: Impair Defenses: Disable or Modify Tools
Use: Ember Bear uses the NirSoft AdvancedRun utility to disable Microsoft Defender Antivirus through stopping the WinDefend service on victim machines. Ember Bear disables Windows Defender via registry key changes.[2]
Ember Bear deletes files related to lateral movement to avoid detection.[2]
Ember Bear retrieves follow-on payloads direct from adversary-owned infrastructure for deployment on compromised hosts.[2]
Ember Bear has enumerated SECURITY and SYSTEM log files during intrusions.[1]
Ember Bear has renamed the legitimate Sysinternals tool procdump to alternative names such as dump64.exe to evade detection.[2]
Ember Bear has renamed tools to match legitimate utilities, such as renaming GOST tunneling instances to java in victim environments.[1]
Ember Bear modifies registry values for anti-forensics and defense evasion purposes.[2]
Ember Bear has used tools such as NMAP for remote system discovery and enumeration in victim environments.[1]

Ember Bear uses socket-based tunneling utilities for command and control purposes such as NetCat and Go Simple Tunnel (GOST). These tunnels are used to push interactive command prompts over the created sockets.[2] Ember Bear has also used reverse TCP connections from Meterpreter installations to communicate back with C2 infrastructure.[1]
Ember Bear has used various non-standard ports for C2 communication.[1]
Ember Bear has acquired malware and related tools from dark web forums.[1]
Ember Bear has obtained exploitation scripts against publicly-disclosed vulnerabilities from public repositories.[1]
Ember Bear gathers credential material from target systems, such as SSH keys, to facilitate access to victim environments.[2]
Ember Bear uses legitimate Sysinternals tools such as procdump to dump LSASS memory.[2][1]
Ember Bear acquires victim credentials by extracting registry hives such as the Security Account Manager through commands such as reg save.[2][1]
Ember Bear has used frameworks such as Impacket to dump LSA secrets for credential capture.[1]
Ember Bear has used ProxyChains to tunnel protocols to internal networks.[1]
Ember Bear has configured multi-hop proxies via ProxyChains within victim environments.[1]
Ember Bear uses valid network credentials gathered through credential harvesting to move laterally within victim networks, often employing the Impacket framework to do so.[2]
Ember Bear has used tools such as Nmap and MASSCAN for remote service discovery.[1]
Ember Bear uses remotely scheduled tasks to facilitate remote command execution on victim machines.[2]

Ember Bear deploys web shells following initial access for either follow-on command execution or protocol tunneling. Example web shells used by Ember Bear include P0wnyshell, reGeorg, P.A.S. Webshell, and custom variants of publicly-available web shell examples.[2][1]

Ember Bear has compromised information technology providers and software developers providing services to targets of interest, building initial access to ultimate victims at least in part through compromise of service providers that work with the victim organizations.[2]
Ember Bear has dumped configuration settings in accessed IP cameras including plaintext credentials.[1]

Full_Technique_Name: Use Alternate Authentication Material: Pass the Hash
Use: Ember Bear has used pass-the-hash techniques for lateral movement in victim environments.[1]
Ember Bear has abused default user names and passwords in externally-accessible IP cameras for initial access.[1]
Ember Bear has exfiltrated images from compromised IP cameras.[1]
Ember Bear has used WMI execution with password hashes for command execution and lateral movement.[1]
Equation has been observed utilizing environmental keying in payload delivery.[2][1]
Equation has used an encrypted virtual file system stored in the Windows Registry.[1]
Equation has used tools with the functionality to search for specific information about the attached hard drive that could be used to identify and overwrite the firmware.[1]
Equation is known to have the capability to overwrite the firmware on hard drives from some manufacturers.[1]

Use: Evilnum has used PowerShell to bypass UAC.[1]

Evilnum can deploy additional components or tools as needed.[1]
Evilnum has sent spearphishing emails containing a link to a zip file hosted on Google Drive.[1]

Evilnum can steal cookies and session information from browsers.[1]
Evilnum has sent spearphishing emails designed to trick the recipient into opening malicious shortcut links which downloads a .LNK file.[1]
Evilnum has used a component called TerraLoader to check certain hardware and file information to detect sandboxed environments. [1]
EXOTIC LILY has registered domains to spoof targeted organizations by changing the top-level domain (TLD) to ".us", ".co" or ".biz".[1]

EXOTIC LILY has used malicious links to lure users into executing malicious payloads.[1]
EXOTIC LILY has gained execution through victims clicking on malicious LNK files contained within ISO files, which can execute hidden DLLs within the ISO.[1][2]
EXOTIC LILY has used file-sharing services including WeTransfer, TransferNow, and OneDrive to deliver payloads.[1]
Ferocious Kitten has acquired domains imitating legitimate sites.[1]

Full_Technique_Name: Command and Scripting Interpreter: Visual Basic
Use: FIN13 has used VBS scripts for code execution on comrpomised machines.[2]

FIN13 has researched employees to target for social engineering attacks.[1]

FIN13 has executed net view commands for enumeration of open shares on compromised machines.[1][2]
FIN13 has utilized publicly available tools such as Mimikatz, Impacket, PWdump7, ProcDump, Nmap, and Incognito V2 for targeting efforts.[2]

FIN13 has utilized a proxy tool to communicate between compromised assets.[2]

FIN13 has remotely accessed compromised environments via secure shell (SSH) for lateral movement.[1]
FIN13 has leveraged WMI to move laterally within a compromised network via application servers and SQL servers.[2]
FIN13 has created scheduled tasks in the C:\Windows directory of the compromised network.[1]

FIN13 has collected local host information by utilizing Windows commands systeminfo, fsutil, and fsinfo. FIN13 has also utilized a compromised Symantex Altiris console and LanDesk account to retrieve host information.[1][2]
FIN13 has used nslookup and ipconfig for network reconnaissance efforts. FIN13 has also utilized a compromised Symantec Altiris console and LanDesk account to retrieve network information.[1][2]
FIN13 has used Ping and tracert for network reconnaissance efforts.[1]
FIN13 has used netstat and other net  commands for network reconnaissance efforts.[1]
FIN13 has obtained administrative credentials by browsing through local files on a compromised machine.[2]

FIN13 has utilized WMI to execute commands and move laterally on compromised Windows machines.[1][2]

FIN4 has lured victims to click malicious links delivered via spearphishing emails (often sent from compromised accounts).[1][3]
